message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ECG suggests a supraventricular tachycardia. Adenosine is the drug of choice for acute management of supraventricular tachycardia. Verapamil and Metoprolol can also be used, but Adenosine has a faster onset of action. Propafenone is used for atrial fibrillation/flutter.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ECG shows supraventricular tachycardia, and Adenosine is the preferred agent for pharmacologic management of this condition. Verapamil and Diltiazem can also be used, but Adenosine has a shorter half-life and can act faster. Metoprolol and Propafenone are not the preferred agents for acute treatment of supraventricular tachycardia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting symptoms of supraventricular tachycardia, and the ECG confirms it. Adenosine is the preferred agent for pharmacologic management of this condition as it helps to slow down the heart rate by blocking electrical signals in the heart. Verapamil and metoprolol are also used for this condition, but adenosine is the first-line treatment. Propafenone is used for other arrhythmias, not supraventricular tachycardia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), as seen on the ECG. Adenosine is the preferred agent for acute management of SVT. Verapamil and Diltiazem are also potential options, but Adenosine is preferred due to its rapid onset of action. Metoprolol and Propafenone are not first-line agents for acute SVT management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The exhibit shows a narrow complex tachycardia, which is most likely supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Adenosine is the preferred agent for pharmacologic management of SVT. Verapamil and diltiazem can also be used but are contraindicated in patients with pre-excited atrial fibrillation with a history of Wolff–Parkinson–White syndrome, and metoprolol and propafenone are not as effective in terminating SVT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The exhibit shows narrow-complex tachycardia, indicating supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Adenosine is the preferred agent for pharmacologic management of SVT. Verapamil and Metoprolol are also used to treat SVT, but Adenosine is the preferred agent for acute management of symptoms. Propafenone is used for the management of atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ECG shows regular narrow complex tachycardia, which is most likely supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Adenosine is the preferred agent for pharmacologic management of SVT. Verapamil and diltiazem are also effective, but they can cause hypotension, which is not desirable for this patient with already elevated blood pressure. Metoprolol and propafenone can also be used, but adenosine is the first-line treatment for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ECG shows supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), which can be treated with adenosine. Verapamil and metoprolol are other options, but adenosine is preferred for acute treatment. Propafenone is used for atrial fibrillation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ECG shows regular wide complex tachycardia, which is likely ventricular tachycardia. Adenosine is the preferred agent for pharmacologic management of stable ventricular tachycardia. Verapamil and Metoprolol are used for other types of tachycardia, and Propafenone is contraindicated in ventricular tachycardia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ECG shows a regular narrow complex tachycardia, which is likely supraventricular tachycardia. Adenosine is the preferred agent for pharmacologic management of this condition. Verapamil and Diltiazem can also be used, but they are contraindicated in patients with hypotension or heart failure. Metoprolol can be used for rate control, but it does not terminate the tachycardia. Propafenone is used for rhythm control, but it is not the preferred agent in this situation.
